Prodb API

Create pandas dataframe for manipulation

1.0 Generate Db

Initialise database with generate_db call.

{% raw %}

generate_db[source]

generate_db(dbpath='db.csv', cols=['c1', 'c2', 'c3'], prefill=False)

Create example database

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %}

Generate empty db object with arbitary columns.

{% raw %} 
df = generate_db(cols=['c1', 'c2', 'c3'])
df.head()

âœ“ðŸ’¾ db.csv (10 kb)
c1 c2 c3
{% endraw %}

Generate db with some example data.

{% raw %} 
df = generate_db(prefill=True)
df.head()

âœ“ðŸ’¾ db.csv (99 kb)
name mood message time_utc
0 Sam ðŸ˜Š hi 2021-11-04 14:58:59
1 Grant ðŸ˜µ hello 2021-11-04 14:58:59
{% endraw %}

2.0 Insert Row

{% raw %}

insert_row[source]

insert_row(df, data, dbpath='db.csv')

{% endraw %} {% raw %}

insert_rows[source]

insert_rows(df, data, dbpath='db.csv')

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %}

Example: Insert single row

{% raw %} 
df = generate_db(cols='name mood message'.split())

# ================================================================ #

data = {'name':'George', 'mood': 'ðŸ‘¹', 'message':'hi'}
df = insert_row(df, data)

# ================================================================ #

display(df)

âœ“ðŸ’¾ db.csv (19 kb)
name mood message
0 George ðŸ‘¹ hi
{% endraw %}

Example: Insert multiple rows

Note: prodb allows additional columns to be added after the database has been initialised.

i.e. the ['name', 'mood', 'message'] columns that initialise the db, play nice when the additional time_utc dict is passed in. NaNs are imputed for previous rows.

First, a helper function to clean up timestamp calls.

{% raw %}

utc_now[source]

utc_now()

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
df = generate_db(cols='name mood message'.split())

# ================================================================ #

data = {'name': ['Sam', 'Grant'],
        'mood': ['ðŸ˜Š', 'ðŸ˜µ'],
        'message': ['hello from London, UK', 'hello from Christchurch, NZ'],
        'time_utc' : [utc_now(), utc_now()]}

df = insert_rows(df, data)

# ================================================================ #

display(df)

âœ“ðŸ’¾ db.csv (19 kb)
name mood message time_utc
0 Sam ðŸ˜Š hello from London, UK 2021-11-04 15:04:55
1 Grant ðŸ˜µ hello from Christchurch, NZ 2021-11-04 15:04:55
{% endraw %}

Add another entry to the bottom of the database using insert_row().

Note: Data columns from dictionary do not need to be in pre-defined order.

{% raw %} 
data = {'time_utc' : utc_now(),
        'name': 'Luke', 
        'mood': 'ðŸ‘¹', 
        'message': 'hello from London, UK'}
df = insert_row(df, data)

display(df)
name mood message time_utc
0 Sam ðŸ˜Š hello from London, UK 2021-11-04 15:04:55
1 Grant ðŸ˜µ hello from Christchurch, NZ 2021-11-04 15:04:55
2 Luke ðŸ‘¹ hello from London, UK 2021-11-04 15:04:57
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
data = {'name':'Bill', 'mood': 'ðŸ‘¹', 'message':'hi', 'time_utc':arrow.utcnow().format('YYYY-MM-DD HH:mm:ss')}
df = insert_row(df, data)
display(df)
name mood message time_utc
0 Sam ðŸ˜Š hello from London, UK 2021-11-04 15:04:55
1 Grant ðŸ˜µ hello from Christchurch, NZ 2021-11-04 15:04:55
2 Luke ðŸ‘¹ hello from London, UK 2021-11-04 15:04:57
3 Bill ðŸ‘¹ hi 2021-11-04 15:04:58
{% endraw %} {% raw %}

display_readable[source]

display_readable(df, max_rows=8)

{% endraw %} {% raw %}
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
data = {'name':'Bill', 
        'mood': 'ðŸ˜Š', 
        'message':'hello, from UK',
        'time_utc':utc_now()}
df = insert_row(df, data)
display_readable(df)
name mood message time_utc human_time
2 Luke ðŸ‘¹ hello from London, UK 2021-11-04 15:04:57 3 minutes ago
3 Bill ðŸ‘¹ hi 2021-11-04 15:04:58 3 minutes ago
4 Bill ðŸ‘¹ hi 2021-11-04 15:06:34 2 minutes ago
5 Bill ðŸ‘¹ hi 2021-11-04 15:06:44 a minute ago
6 Bill ðŸ˜Š hello, from UK 2021-11-04 15:07:10 a minute ago
7 Bill ðŸ˜Š hello, from UK 2021-11-04 15:08:15 27 seconds ago
8 Bill ðŸ˜Š hello, from UK 2021-11-04 15:08:17 25 seconds ago
9 Bill ðŸ˜Š hello, from UK 2021-11-04 15:08:42 just now
